title: Markov Chain Monte Carlo in Cryptography

data.title: Markov Chain Monte Carlo in Cryptography
data.statement:
The Markov Chain Monte Carlo (or MCMC) methods comprise a class of algorithms for sampling from a probability distribution. It can be used to decrypt a message encrypted by a substitution cypher.
The goal here is to find out the cypher alphabet used to encrypt a message.
This cypher method is simple: replace every letter in your unencrypted message by another one at the same place in your cypher alphabet.
For example:
`Plaintext Alphabet: ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ`
` Cypher Alphabet :  ZAYBXCWDVEUFTGSHRIQKPKOLNM`
Using this alphabet to encrypt "HELLO WORLD" will give "DXFFS OSIFB", with each letter in the original message replaced by the one right below it in the second alphabet.

To decrypt such a message, you can't try every possibility, as there are 26 letters in the alphabet, that means there is 26! possibilities (Roughly 4e26).
So to do so, you can use statistics, for instance, as you know that roughly 13% of letters in English are an {{E}}, you can guess that a letter appearing around 13% of the time in a message is originally an {{E}}. 
That works, but only for message thousands of characters long, so the MCMC method use as well the probability that a given letter is followed by another, (e.g. in English, around 21% of {{i}} are followed by a {{n}}).

The likelihood of a text is therefore the product of every following letter probability in the text.
The way to calculate the likelihood here is : {{sum(ln(L([[i]],[[i]]+1)+1e-6))}} with [[i]] being the [[i]]-th character of the sentence and {{L([[i]],[[i]]+1)}} being the likelihood of any [[i]]-th character being followed by the ([[i]]{{+1}})-th character.
For example:
{{L(Markov) = (ln(L(ma)+1e-6)+ln(L(ar)+1e-6) + ... + ln(L(ov)+1e-6)) = -19.072}}
The higher the value, the more likely it is to be the correct answer, the theoretical maximum is 0 but you will in reality never get that much.
Any non-letter character should be treated as a white-space.
Ignore the case of the characters.
The likelihood of having a space following an {{a}} is meaningful, it represents the proportion of words ending in {{a}}, but the likelihood of a space followed by another space is meaningless as spaces aren't encrypted.
Please note that you can compute it using other methods. The [[expected_likelihood]] value is provided only as an optional helper to verify that you have found the correct answer; it is not required for solving the puzzle.

As there is not enough space in the statement area to write in a readable way all of the stats you may need, here is a link to the whole thing, with template for some languages so you do not have to copy everything by hand:
{{https://github.com/Diabetos/CG/tree/main/MCMC}}

All those stats and tests cases are from Dante's Inferno:
{{https://wyomingcatholic.edu/wp-content/uploads/dante-01-inferno.pdf}}

testCases.title: Canto 2
testCases.testIn:
-2847.5304417621674
“Upon this journey, whence thou givest him vaunt, Things did he hear, which the occasion were Both of his victory and the papal mantle. Thither went afterwards the Chosen Vessel, To bring back comfort thence unto that Faith, Which of salvation’s way is the beginning. But I, why thither come, or who concedes it? I not Aenas am, I am not Paul, Nor I, nor others, think me worthy of it. Therefore, if I resign myself to come, I fear the coming may be ill-advised; Thou’rt wise, and knowest better than I speak.” And as he is, who unwills what he willed, And by new thoughts doth his intention change, So that from his design he quite withdraws, Such I became, upon that dark hillside, Because, in thinking, I consumed the emprise, Which was so very prompt in the beginning. “If I have well thy language understood,” Replied that shade of the Magnanimous, “Thy soul attainted is with cowardice, Which many times a man encumbers so, It turns him back from honoured enterprise, As false sight doth a beast, when he is shy. That thou mayst free thee from this apprehension, I’ll tell thee why I came, and what I heard At the first moment when I grieved for thee. Among those was I who are in suspense, And a fair, saintly Lady called to me In such wise, I besought her to command me. Her eyes where shining brighter than the Star;

data.stubGenerator:
read expectedLikelihood:float
read text:string(1499)

STATEMENT
A template to collect the stats can be found following this link:
https://github.com/Diabetos/CG/tree/main/MCMC


write answer
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1>>: A float [[expected_likelihood]], the likelihood you will have if you test the likelihood of the original text (used to know when to stop the program).
<<Line 2>>: The [[text]] to decypher.
data.outputDescription: The cypher alphabet, in uppercase. If a character never appears, replace it by a dot ({{.}})

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

The Markov Chain Monte Carlo (or MCMC) methods comprise a class of algorithms for sampling from a probability distribution. It can be used to decrypt a message encrypted by a substitution cypher.
The goal here is to find out the cypher alphabet used to encrypt a message.
This cypher method is simple: replace every letter in your unencrypted message by another one at the same place in your cypher alphabet.
For example:
Plaintext Alphabet: ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ

 Cypher Alphabet :  ZAYBXCWDVEUFTGSHRIQKPKOLNM

Using this alphabet to encrypt "HELLO WORLD" will give "DXFFS OSIFB", with each letter in the original message replaced by the one right below it in the second alphabet.

To decrypt such a message, you can't try every possibility, as there are 26 letters in the alphabet, that means there is 26! possibilities (Roughly 4e26).
So to do so, you can use statistics, for instance, as you know that roughly 13% of letters in English are an E, you can guess that a letter appearing around 13% of the time in a message is originally an E.
That works, but only for message thousands of characters long, so the MCMC method use as well the probability that a given letter is followed by another, (e.g. in English, around 21% of i are followed by a n).

The likelihood of a text is therefore the product of every following letter probability in the text.
The way to calculate the likelihood here is : sum(ln(L(i,i+1)+1e-6)) with i being the i-th character of the sentence and L(i,i+1) being the likelihood of any i-th character being followed by the (i+1)-th character.
For example:
L(Markov) = (ln(L(ma)+1e-6)+ln(L(ar)+1e-6) + ... + ln(L(ov)+1e-6)) = -19.072
The higher the value, the more likely it is to be the correct answer, the theoretical maximum is 0 but you will in reality never get that much.
Any non-letter character should be treated as a white-space.
Ignore the case of the characters.
The likelihood of having a space following an a is meaningful, it represents the proportion of words ending in a, but the likelihood of a space followed by another space is meaningless as spaces aren't encrypted.
Please note that you can compute it using other methods. The expected_likelihood value is provided only as an optional helper to verify that you have found the correct answer; it is not required for solving the puzzle.

As there is not enough space in the statement area to write in a readable way all of the stats you may need, here is a link to the whole thing, with template for some languages so you do not have to copy everything by hand:
https://github.com/Diabetos/CG/tree/main/MCMC

All those stats and tests cases are from Dante's Inferno:
https://wyomingcatholic.edu/wp-content/uploads/dante-01-inferno.pdf
Input
Line 1: A float expected_likelihood, the likelihood you will have if you test the likelihood of the original text (used to know when to stop the program).
Line 2: The text to decypher.
Output
The cypher alphabet, in uppercase. If a character never appears, replace it by a dot (.)
Constraints
1 < Length of the text < 1500
-4000 < expected_likelihood < 0
Example
Input
-2561.1156814046317
Kbz gvtruba rhtj qz kt qrlb bzocyjzkk, Iyab abz onnvyuba aboa nvtq bzv okhzla loqz, Aboa Y abz bthz vzdyjsrykbze tn abz bzyuba. Oje ok bz yk ibt iyddyjudm olsryvzk, Oje abz ayqz ltqzk aboa lorkzk byq at dtkz, Ibt izzhk yj odd byk abtrubak oje yk ezkhtjezja, Z’zj krlb qoez qz aboa gzoka iyabtrazj hzolz, Ibylb, ltqyju tj ouoyjka qz gm ezuvzzk Abvrka qz golx abyabzv ibzvz abz krj yk kydzja Ibydz Y iok vrkbyju etijiove at abz dtidoje, Gzntvz qyjz zmzk eye tjz hvzkzja byqkzdn, Ibt kzzqze nvtq dtju-ltjayjrze kydzjlz btovkz.
